I too am very interested in where people draw the line between unit testing and integration testing.
Humphrey Sheil in his JavaWorld article "J2EE project dangers!"

http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-03-2001/jw-0330-ten_p.html

says that he would like to talk about: 'Unit testing versus integration testing (when is testing done?)'

Has anyone got any thoughts or references on the differences between unit testing and integration testing. Some questions spring to mind:

When should each be done?
What you are trying to achieve with each?
What asumptions you can make with each?

Thanks

-----Original Message-----
From: nsparis [mailto:nathan_paris@...]
Sent: 13 November 2002 15:56
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [junit] Re: Best approach for Unit testing asynch responses?


You are referring to what I am doing as an "integration" test.  Do 
you think this is no longer a unit test when I start making sure that 
the messenger is respondeing correctly when something is added?  

Should the unit test only make sure that the addMessage() method is 
working (I.e. it received the message), and the integration test 
should then make sure that when a certain message is added it 
recieves the correct response message via the listener?

Thanks

--- In junit@y..., "Michael Rettig" <mrettig@h...> wrote:
> ----- Original Message -----
> From: Mike Clark <mike@c...>
> > >I have already implemented this with JUnit by making the 
> > >TestMessenger TestCase a MessengerLister.  After I add a message 
I 
> > >sleep until a response is supplied. I then wake up (or time out 
for 
> > >failure) and test if this is the correct response to assert if 
the 
> > >test failed or passed. 
> > >
> > 
> > Sounds like a reasonable integration test.  That's generally the 
> > approach I take when faced with testing asynchronous messaging 
end-to-end.
> > 
> > Mike
> 
> Also, you can look at mocking your messenger layer. Whenever, I've 
done asynch testing, I found a way to make the testing synchronouse 
using a mock layer. This was ideal for simulating odd messaging 
behavior that could not be easily replicated asynchronously.  
> 
> Mike Rettig
